awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the research of Professor Kami L. Hull of the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign to develop new approaches for the synthesis of carbonyl containing compounds. Such species are extremely important in the commodity chemical industry as well as in pharmaceutical and specialty chemical syntheses. Their preparations, however, are complicated and often involve the production of undesirable by-products. One of the primary goals of this project is to maximize the economy of the synthesis of these species. The development of new methodologies that minimize waste are targeted for the synthesis of amides, esters, thioesters, and ketones, all of which are important starting materials or intermediates in large scale chemical processes. The broader impacts this work include the potential to minimize the waste associated with the synthesis of carbonyl compounds, thereby making better use of our natural resources in the synthesis of fine and commodity chemicals. Additionally, there is an outreach component that aims to increase the scientific literacy of rural children and encourage these students to pursue higher education in STEM disciplines.

New rhodium based metal-catalysts are developed that allow for the direct coupling of alcohols and nucleophiles, through dehydrogenation or transfer hydrogenation, for the synthesis of amides, esters, thioesters and ketones. Further, synthesis of alpha and beta chiral carbonyl compounds is explored. The catalysts and organic products are fully characterized by NMR spectroscopy, IR spectroscopy, and X-ray crystallography, when needed. To increase the scientific understanding of the greater community, an outreach program entitled Next Generation of Illinois Scientists (NGIS) is developed. The goals of NGIS is to bring scientific outreach to rural communities. Working with fourth grade students at rural elementary schools within a 50 mile radius of the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign a series of experiments is developed that builds on the Common Core Curriculum.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The University of Texas at Austin

por.por_cntn:
Carbon-nitrogen bonds are prominent in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and organic materials. Unfortunately, their synthesis is often inefficient with respect to both time and resources. This project accelerated the synthesis while minimizing the waste generated to access amides by developing the Rh-catalyzed oxidative functionalization of allylic alcohols and amines via transfer dehydrogenation where styrene or acetone serves as the hydrogen acceptor. We then demonstrated that under related conditions, using commercially available catalysts and ligands, we could oxidatively amidate very sterically hindered alcohols and aldehydes. One of the primary challenges addressed was the development of asymmetric processes. We demonstrated that by using enamines, rather than allylic alcohols, we could asymmetrically synthesize b-substituted amides in good to excellent yields and outstanding enantiomeric excesses (Figure 1c).5 We were able to develop conditions for the oxidative amidation with secondary cyclic, primary and secondary acyclic amines, as well as anilines. This methodology allows us to synthesize otherwise challenging stereocenters, such as that shown in Figure 1c, where the only difference is an additional methylene group. Further, we identified conditions that allowed for the asymmetric synthesis of b-substituted esters (Figure 1d). Finally, we developed the photocatalytic hydro(amino)alkylation of terminal alkenes. The reactions developed herein were both step and atom economical and rapidly allow access to important functionalities. The efficiency of these methods was highlighted in the synthesis of a number of pharmaceuticals, including Detrol-LA and Sensipar.

 

In addition to the broader scientific impacts included partially funding the training of six graduate and eight undergraduate students. The PI has also been involved in many efforts outside the laboratory to support the great chemical community and beyond. She has reviewed over 50 publications for a wide variety of journals and served on both NSF and NIH review panels. She is currently the technical director for the Southwest Regional ACS Meeting being held in Austin in Fall 2021. In this role she has assembled almost 400 oral presentations and 250 posters, collaborating with the other organizers to ensure an exciting meeting. She is also a symposium organizer for PacifiChem 2020 (now 2021), working with professors from three other Pacific Rim countries on the topic of remote functionalization.

Since joining the Department of Chemistry at UT Austin 2018, Hull has made it a priority to ensure that all students have access to a diverse, equitable, and inclusive education in the Chemistry Department. Hull began the DEI Task Force within the Chemistry Department at UT Austin that seeks to improve the department and make it a place where all students are welcome and supported throughout their education. Together with a student lead committee we are making great strides here at UT Austin. Finally, Hull has become the instructor for ChemBridge, a Dual Enrollment Initiative, that allows high school students to take college courses. This program is aimed at students who will be first generation college attendees and who are predominantly Latinx.

 


Last Modified: 04/28/2023
Modified by: Kami Hull

Image

    Kami Lee Hull

Carbon-nitrogen bonds are prominent in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and organic materials. Unfortunately, their synthesis is often inefficient with respect to both time and resources. The PI has also been involved in many efforts outside the laboratory to support the great chemical community and beyond. She has reviewed over 50 publications for a wide variety of journals and served on both NSF and NIH review panels.
